Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Block Copolymer Compatibilizers for Controlled Morphology and Interfacial Properties in Polymer-Fullerene Blends

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs have previously found that a hierarchical morphology of donor and acceptor domains led to a high yield of electron transfer, enhanced exciton dissociation, and a high power conversion efficiency (PCE). In this proposal, they seek to combine theory and experiments in a coordinated approach to manipulate the nanostructured hierarchical morphologies in a controlled manner in order to quantify the influence of different morphological length scales on the optoelectronic properties and the efficiencies of solar cells composed of a semi-conducting donor and the fullerene acceptor system, PCBM. One way to ensure increased contact between the donor and acceptor phases is to use block copolymers (BCP), PTB7, as ?compatiblizers? to meld the two phases. Their approach is to find what the ?design rules? are for OPVs by undertaking a systematic combined experimental-theoretical investigation for designing efficient compatibilizers in the context of OPV applications. Their general plan is to synthesize PTB7 block copolymers, measure the รท-interaction parameter between model polymer blocks, PTB7, and fullerene in thin film, multilayer blends, then elucidate and correlate the thermodynamics and microstructures of the BHJ blends to the morphology and optoelectronic properties of bulk heterojunction photovoltaics with PTB7 block copolymer compatibilizers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The amount of energy in just one hour of sunlight is sufficient to power the planet for an entire year. However, electricity from solar energy provides only a small fraction of the energy consumption worldwide. New materials that can harvest sunlight and produce electricity are needed in order to increase the impact of solar energy technologies. In particular, polymers can be used in the design of thin, flexible, and lightweight solar cells, in contrast to the heavy and inflexible silicon-based devices.  These can provide access to a new class of flexible and portable devices that can harvest solar energy. However, the performance of state-of-the-art polymer-based solar cells is inadequate for widespread commercial use. The efficiency of conversion of light to electricity is much lower compared with silicon solar cells. To address this limitation, the goal of this project is to develop low-cost approaches for improving the performance of polymer-based solar cells. Importantly, methods for improving performance should maintain a low-cost and ease-of-processing. Specifically, our work focuses on the design and development of polymer-based additives that can improve the stability and performance of photovoltaic devices. In conjunction with the research objectives, the project has a number of educational objectives, including multidisciplinary training of graduate students, mentoring and training of undergraduate students, including students from Houston-area community colleges, and outreach programs to increase awareness and understanding of alternative energy technologies.

 

A major challenge of the work was designing the proper additives and understanding the effect of additives on the structure and electronic properties of the polymer solar cells. While polymer solar cells are straightforward to fabricate, the active materials in the polymer-based solar cells have a highly complex structure. In the best performing solar devices, the active material is comprised of two components (to carry positive and negative charges), and these two components are highly mixed and interweaving. In order to design proper additives that can stabilize this complex structure, we took advantage of computational simulations for guiding the design of the additives that could produce a structure ideal for the polymer-based solar cells. We also used various advanced characterization tools capable of visualizing the molecular-level structure of the polymer solar cells. Ultimately, we designed additives that are compatible with low-cost, solution processing techniques standard in the commercial polymers industry. These materials can potentially lead to polymer solar cells with significantly improved device efficiencies and more stable performance. A number of students and research scientists benefitted from the collaborative project that extended across two universities in Texas and included collaborators across the country.
